metadata.title: The role of pH and nitrate concentration in the wet chemical growth of nano-rods shaped ZnO photocatalyst

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano-Structures & Nano-Objects
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoso
The role of pH and nitrate concentration in the wet chemical growth of nano-rods shaped ZnO photocatalyst Rohini Singh a,∗, Suman Dutta b a Department of Chemical Engineering, Sitarambhai Naranji Patel Institute of Technology & Research Centre, Bardoli, Gujarat 394345, India b Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, Jharkhand 826004, India
h i g h l i g h t s
• Synthesis and characterisation of ZnO nanorods via wet chemical method. • Effect determination of pH and nitrate concentration on the overall growth of prepared ZnO nano-rods. • Photocatalytic activity evaluation of the prepared ZnO via dye degradation and hydrogen generation under simulated solar irradiation.
gra ph i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 28 September 2018 Received in revised form 20 December 2018 Accepted 15 January 2019
Keywords: ZnO nano-rods Photocatalyst Wet chemical method Photo degradation
a b s t r a c t
ZnO nano-rods were synthesised via wet chemical method at different nitrate concentration and pH value. The effect of pH and nitrate concentration on the size and morphology of the prepared ZnO photocatalysts have been investigated by particle size distribution analysis and Field emission scanning electron microscopy respectively. Additionally, UV-Visible spectroscopy and energy dispersive studies and were carried out to confirm the optical and compositional properties of the prepared ZnO powder. The estimated band gap of the as prepared ZnO photocatalysts at different pH and nitrate concentration calculated on the basis of Kubelka–Munk function was found to be in the range of ∼2.7–3.6 eV. Field emission scanning (FE-SEM) and transmission electron microscopic (TEM) observations reveal rod-like morphology. The photocatalytic activity of prepared ZnO photocatalysts was evaluated by photo degradation of the mixture of Methylene Blue (MB) and Rhodamine 6G (Rh 6G) solution under simulated solar radiation. Volume of hydrogen evolution was recorded in the presence of prepared ZnO photocatalysts in 2 h. Nitrate concentration, and pH value showed a significant effect on the optical and morphological behaviour of the prepared ZnO powdered photocatalysts.

1. Introduction
ZnO is a wide and direct band gap n-type semiconductor photocatalyst with high electron mobility and excellent chemical stability. It exhibits high exciton binding energy of ∼60 meV and
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: rohini.singh@snpitrc.ac.in (R. Singh).
bandgap energy of ∼3.37–4.2 eV at room temperature [1,2]. Nano sized ZnO is considered as a promising photocatalyst and has been widely investigated by the researchers in the recent years due to their unique physical, chemical, optical, electronic and piezoelectric properties which leads to its potential technological applications [3–10]. A number of methods for ZnO nanostructure preparation have been reported, such as-microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis [11,12], solvothermal process [13] reflux method [14], sonochemical synthesis [15], thermal decomposition
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoso.2019.01.009 2352-507X/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
method [16], sol–gel method [17,18] and many more. Yulizar et al. [19] investigated a method of green synthesis of ZnO/CuO nanocomposite using Theobroma cacao seed bark extract. The well aligned phosphorous doped ZnO have been prepared via two step process comprises of sputtering and chemical growth [20]. Zinc oxide (ZnO) and ZnO–ZnS nanocomposite materials have been synthesised via chemical coprecipitation method [21]. Manthina and Agrios successfully carried out chemical bath deposition method to prepare nanostructured ZnO [22]. Various ZnO nanocomposites were synthesised and characterised by Subhan et al. [23] via co-precipitation method. These synthesis methods involve costly equipment and complex methodology. Wet chemical method is a simple and economical method and the derived ZnO shows high chemical stability [24]. Different ZnO nanostructures i.e. nanorods [25–31], nanobelts [32], nanotubes, nanodiscs [33] nanopencils [34], nanoflowers [35,36], nanoparticles [37–39], nanoneedles [40], nanowires [41], nanoflakes [42] and nanosheets have been successfully synthesised and characterised in the previously reported literatures using wet chemical method [43]. Aluminium-doped zinc oxide (AZO) nanoflowers were successfully fabricated by co-precipitation method [44]. Ebrahimi et al. [45] and Liu et al. [46] prepared ZnO nanowire arrays whereas, Gurylev et al. [47] and Yu et al. [48] synthesised ZnO nanorods and N, C, S doped ZnO with enhanced photocatalytic activity. Karimizadeh et al. [49] fabricated 3-D Multilayer Graphene Foam/ ZnO nanorod Composites with enhanced photocatalytic application. Chakraborty and Kumbhakar (2013) [50] synthesised ZnO twin nanorods by a simple wet chemical method. Hierarchical ZnO arrays assembled by nanosheets and nanorods were prepared by Yue et al. (2009) [51] through a facile solutionbasedwet chemicalmethod. Samanta et al. (2013) [52] successfully used a simple wet chemical method to fabricated very thin and ultra-long ZnO nanoplates. Chen and Gao (2006) [53] prepared ZnO nanorod arrays with controlled size on different substrates. Samanta and Mishra (2013) [54] reported the fabrication of ZnO nanodiscs by a simple wet chemical method. Flower-like zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods were successfully synthesised by Zhang and Yin (2013) [55] via wet chemical method at a relatively low temperature (90 ◦C). Numerous other researchers have worked on the similar process as listed in Tables 1 and 2. However, a fundamental understanding of the effect of preparation parameters on the growth mechanism is essential for the synthesis of effective ZnO nanorods. Therefore, in the present research, effect of nitrate concentration and pH in the synthesis of ZnO nanorods by wet
chemical process is studied exclusively. In addition, more detailed characterisation of the prepared ZnO nanorods has been done to explain their optical, structural and morphological properties. Moreover, photocatalytic responses of the prepared ZnO were evaluated via dye degradation and hydrogen generation reactions.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
All the chemicals were of analytical grade and were not purified further. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate [Zn(NO3)2.6H2O], sodium hydroxide (NaOH), ethanol and commercial ZnO were purchased from Merck. Methylene blue and Rhodamine 6G were obtained from LOBAL Chemie. Properties and structure of the dyes utilised in the dye degradation experiments are shown in our previous work [72].
2.2. Synthesis of ZnO photocatalyst by wet chemical method
ZnO nanopowder was synthesised via simple and cost effective wet chemical method at different nitrate concentration and pH values. Initially, zinc nitrate hexahydrate solutions were prepared with different molar concentrations. Then, the prepared nitrate solutions were mixed with 1 M NaOH solution for 2 h via vigorous stirring to formhomogeneous solution. After 2 h of stirring at room temperature (30 ± 2 ◦C) and pH value of 4.5, white precipitate appeared at the bottom of the beaker that were further filtered, washed anddried overnight at 60 ◦C.Differentmolar concentration (1 M, 3 M, 5 M) of nitrates were utilised to observe effect of the same on the overall growth phenomena. According to the absorption spectra shown in Fig. 1, nitrate concentration of 3 M exhibits higher optical response towards visible radiations. Therefore, to explain the influence of pHon the overall process, further synthesis were done utilising 3 M nitrate concentration in the acidic (pH = 4.5) and alkaline (pH = 10.5) medium. The oven dried as prepared ZnO sampleswere calcined inmuffle furnace at 500 ◦C for 2 h in the presence of air. The code and synthesis parameter of the prepared ZnO samples were listed in Table 3.
Mechanism of ZnO synthesis Based on several proposedmechanism [73,74], zinc nitrate hexahydrate reacts with sodium hydroxide and leads to the formation of Zn(OH)2 precipitate and initiates the formation of ZnO nuclei as shown in Eq. (1).
Zn(NO3)2.6H2O + 2NaOH → Zn(OH)2 + 2NaNO3 + 6H2O (1)
In the subsequent process, zinc hydroxide undergoes hydrothermal decomposition to form Tetrahydroxozinc complex ion, [Zn(OH)4]2− which further reacts with water to give ZnO followed by further growth as represented in Eqs. (2) and (3).
Zn(OH)2 + 2H2O → Zn2+ + 2OH− + 2H2O
→ [Zn(OH)4]2− + 2H+ (2)
Zn(OH)2−4 → ZnO + H2O + 2OH − (3)
2.3. Characterisation of photocatalyst
The absorption spectra of the synthesised ZnO were recorded with UV–Visible spectrophotometer (Agilent Cary 5000). Themorphology and structure of the particles were observed using a field emission scanning electron microscopy (Supra 55 Carl Zeiss Germany) and transmission electron microscopic (Philips CM 200) images. The compositions of the prepared samples weremeasured by energy dispersive spectrometry. The crystal phase and the crystallite size of the prepared samples were observed using X-ray diffraction (Bruker 2nd Gen D2 Phaser).

2.4. Photocatalytic activity measurements
Dye degradation The photocatalytic activity of prepared ZnO samples was evaluated by monitoring the photodegradation of methylene blue (MB) and Rhodamine 6G (Rh 6G)mixture in aqueous solution. Solar simulated lamp is used in photocatalytic reactors to produce similar spectrum like sunlight. The specifications of the lamp used in the experiment are same as illustrated in our previous work [72]. 50 mg/l dye solution in equal proportion was utilised in the experiments to check the photoactivity of the prepared photocatalysts. Prepared photocatalysts were suspended in the Methylene blue and Rhodamine 6G dye solution for effective degradation. A 500 ml beaker was utilised as a reactor for performing dye degradation experiments. However, theworking volume of the reactor was 250 ml, containing dye solution and photocatalyst suspension. 0.5 g ZnO samples were added into a 250 ml of MB and Rh 6G mixed dye solution maintained at the pH of 10.
The solution was stirred continuously at 500 rpm by magnetic stirrer in dark for 60 min for the powder to absorb the dye in the solution and reach absorption desorption equilibrium. At the end of first 60 min, a sample of 5 ml was taken from the suspension by means of syringe filters (0.22 µm) for spectrophotometer measurements. After the first measurement, the solar lampwas turned on and changes in the concentration of dye in the solution through absorbance under simulated solar radiation were measured after every 60 min till 5 h of continuous irradiation and stirring. Dye concentration was measured using UV–Vis spectroscopy. Effective stirring of dye solution and photocatalyst is required in order to maintain the uniform dispersion of the photocatalyst with reduced agglomeration. Therefore, stirring with magnetic bar is required for proper mixing. Thus, reaction sites increases due to proper
mixing and rate of reaction get enhanced. Proper enclosure aid is required to maintain darkness inside the reaction system during dark adsorption and to avoid the external optical disturbances. In order tomaintain the temperature inside the enclosure, an exhaust fan is required.
Hydrogen generation The specifications of the lamp used in the experiment are same as that of dye degradation experiments. The distance from the lamp to the top surface of the round bottom flask was fixed to 7.5 cm. A magnetic stirrerwas used for the uniformmixing of the suspension of catalyst. A 500 ml borosilicate glass round bottom flask was used as a batch reactor. The round bottom flask was covered with rubber septum to avoid leakage of produced gases during reaction. This rubber septum also acts as sample collection port. Fig. 2(a and b) shows the overall experimental set-up for the hydrogen generation experiments. The photocatalytic hydrogen generation reaction study was performed at room temperature (30 ± 2◦ C) under atmospheric pressure.
An amount of 0.5 g prepared photocatalyst was dissolved into 250 ml distilled water containing 10% (v/v) ethanol as sacrificial agent. pH of the reaction solution was measured by pH meter. Before irradiation, the photocatalyst solution was stirred continuously at 500 rpm by magnetic stirrer in dark for 60 min. After 2 h of continuous irradiation, a gas sample of 1 ml was taken from the reactor by means of an airtight syringe for chromatographic measurements. The gaseous products were analysed using gas chromatography with argon as the carrier gas.
Hydrogen generation was confirmed by gas chromatography equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and programme specifications as follows.
Injection port temperature—125 ◦C Column—Spherocarb packed column

3. Result and discussions
3.1. Effect of nitrate concentration
Nitrate concentration in the previously described wet chemical synthesis method significantly influences the optical and morphological properties of the prepared ZnO nanostructured photocatalyst. Fig. 1 shows the absorption spectra of commercial and
prepared ZnO photocatalyst at different nitrate concentration and confirmed that 3 M was the optimum nitrate concentration. ZnO prepared using 3Mnitrate concentration exhibits enhanced visible light activity. Difference in the band gap is attributed to the variations in the stoichiometric of the synthesis, the crystalline size and the type of electronic transition. Morphology is another important factor affected by the nitrate concentration. FESEM images in Fig. 3 clearly illustrate themorphology of the preparedphotocatalyst and inferred that ZnO prepared at low nitrate concentration possess irregular shape. As the nitrate concentration is increased, the rod shaped morphology is found due to the 1D prominent growth mechanisms.
3.2. Effect of pH
The pH value plays a vital role in controlling the morphology and size of the prepared nanostructure. The concentration of OH− can significantly affect nucleation and growthbehaviour. Photocatalyst with different size and morphologies exhibit different visible light activity. The enhanced optical response in terms of visible light activity of ZnOprepared via 3Mnitrate solutionwas observed from the absorption spectra as illustrated in the previous section. Therefore, further synthesis were done by considering the nitrate concentration of 3 M at two different pH values i.e. 4.5 (acidic) and 10.5 (alkaline). Fig. 4 illustrates the FESEM images of commercial ZnO and prepared ZnO in acidic and alkaline medium. It can be inferred based on the FESEM images that ZnO prepared in alkaline (pH:10.5) medium exhibits smaller particle size. Field emission scanning electron microscopic observations reveal rod-like morphology, with the average length and width of 101.87 nm and 40.89 nm for Z-10.5 and 1.14µmand 0.4µmfor Z-4.5 respectively. ZnO prepared in the alkaline medium possess nano sized particles. Fig. 5 shows the EDX spectrum of prepared ZnO photocatalyst in acidic and alkaline medium i.e. Z-4.5 and Z-10.5 respectively.
Proper thermal treatment is essential for the stable phase transition and removal of the volatile components from the prepared catalyst. Fig. 6(a) represents the X-ray diffraction spectra of prepared ZnO nanorods before and after calcination. Pattern shown
as before calcination represents as prepared ZnO that consists of mixed phases (hydroxide and oxide) whereas pattern shown as after calcination illustrates the complete removal of Zn(OH)2 phase and its complete conversion to pure ZnO by calcination at 500 ◦C in the presence of air for 2 h. The as-prepared ZnO phase exhibits orthorhombic crystal structure [JCPDS card No. # 20-1435] and calcined ZnO shows pure hexagonal wurtzite crystalline phase [JCPDS card No. # 36-1451]. Absorption spectrum of prepared ZnO photocatalyst before and after thermal treatment is shown in Fig. 6(b) and indicates a significant red shift in the calcined samples. Fig. 7 illustrates TEM image and SAED pattern of asprepared ZnO nanorods by wet chemical method.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanism of photocatalytic dye degradation and hydrogen generation
sections.text:
ZnO consists of valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) and the energy difference between them is called the band gap (Eg ). When ZnO is exposed to the photons with the energy equal or higher than the band gap energy (Eg ), electrons are excited from the valence band to conduction band leaving holes behind in VB and thus forms electron–hole pairs. Initially, the diffusion of organic pollutants takes place from the contaminated solution to the photocatalyst surface. Then, the effective adsorption of the
target pollutants on the pore surface gets executed followed by redox reaction and desorption of the product to the outer surface of the photocatalyst. Thereafter, the removal or separation of the less or non-toxic product to the treated solution gets executed. The fundamental mechanism of photocatalytic hydrogen generation can be illustrated in four different steps namely adsorption, photoexcitation, charge diffusion, and reduction/oxidation reaction. The detailed description of dye degradation and hydrogen generation phenomena has been described in our previous work [75,76].
3.5. Photocatalytic activity evaluation of prepared ZnO
Dye degradation Mixture of Methylene Blue (MB) and Rhodamine 6G (Rh 6G) were utilised as model dyes to estimate the photocatalytic activity
of the prepared ZnO samples under simulated solar radiation. The absorbance curve of MB and Rh 6G mixed solutions after 5 h of irradiation is shown in Fig. 8 using as prepared and calcined ZnO as photocatalyst.
The kinetics of MB and Rh 6G photodegradation on the photocatalyst surface can be described by the first-order reaction as shown in Eq. (4)
ln C0 Ct = kt (4)
where, k is the rate constant (min−1), C0 is the initial concentration of MB and Ct is the concentration of MB at the irradiation time (t). Fig. 9 describes the linear relationship of ln(C0/Ct ) versus irradiation time (t) for the mixture of MB and Rh 6G. Rate constants were determined for all analysed photocatalysts from the slope of linear fitting line as shown in Table 4. As it can be seen, a good correlation to the first order reaction kinetics (r2 > 0.95) was found. It can be observed that calcined ZnO nanorods prepared via wet chemical method exhibits maximum degradation after 5 h of irradiation due to the effective thermal and nano sized effect. In addition to that, it can be observed that each dye degrades differently utilising the same photocatalyst. In our case, Methylene blue degraded faster as compared to Rhodamine 6G (Rh 6G) due to the lower bond dissociation energy ofMB. Degradationmechanism involves the breaking of old bonds and the formation of new ones. Bond dissociation energy (BDE) theory states that chemical bonds with lower BDE are easier to break and conveniently form new bonds [77].
Hydrogen generation A gas chromatograph (Thermofisher scientific trace GC 700) was utilised for the qualitative and quantitative analysis of the generated photocatalytic hydrogen. Furthermore, retention time and corresponding area were employed to determine the corresponding amount of hydrogen produced. The Thermofisher scientific trace GC 700 was equipped with a TCD (Thermal Conductivity Detector) and a FID (Flame ionisation detector), connected in series. Qualitative analysis or identification of hydrogen was done by observing retention time whereas, corresponding area of the peak was utilised for the quantitative analysis of hydrogen. Photocatalytic hydrogen generation at the pH value of 4 over 0.5 g of Z-4.5(500) and Z-10.5(500) were 1972.5 and 2170 mmol/h/g respectively.
4. Conclusions
ZnO derived from wet chemical process exhibits rod shaped morphology with the band gap of 2.7–3.6 eV. Optical response of the ZnO photocatalyst prepared from wet chemical method depends on various factors such as-nitrate concentration, ph and calcination temperature. The wet chemical process derived ZnO photocatalyst prepared in alkaline medium is nano sized as compared to that of in acidic medium. According to dye degradation and hydrogen generation experiment results, the prepared catalysts are highly photoactive. The prepared ZnO photocatalyst prepared in alkaline medium exhibits higher dye degradation activity as compared to that in the acidic medium. Therefore, it can be concluded that particle size of the catalyst play a major role in
their dye degradation activity. In addition, Methylene blue (MB) degraded faster as compared to Rhodamine 6G (Rh 6G) utilising the prepared ZnO photocatalysts.
